Really, if it's a turn-based TTRPG, everybody's more-or-less just picking an effect or change to inflict on the environment or enemies. The way the characters do it is all fluff. Sticking with 5E, Paladins are also "warriors," and obviously have a bevvy of magical/magic-like abilities that they can utilize in addition to their okay social skills and fighter-like combat skills. The Fighter in 5E also has a solid collection of tools to do things other than "hit with sword." 5E's approach to Proficiency and Skills means that you can focus on developing all of their fighting-stuff and they'll just continue to get better at whatever 4-6 skills you chose for them to be proficient at; inherently addressing their lack of out-of-combat utility from ye ol' 3.5. That's just vanilla PHB options too.
